qas.question: The sovereign grants assent by which order?
Who advises the sovereign in this decision?
Which recent petition for reforms to the constitution led to assent being refused?
Who advises a bill to be granted or refused?
When was an Order in Counil passed that laid out new rules for consideration of petitions against the royal assent?
In what year did the Lord Chancellor refuse to present a law  concerning constituational reform for assent?
What was the subject of the bill that the Lord Chancellor refused to present for royal assent in 2007?

answers.text: reforms to the constitution of the Chief Pleas of Sark

qas.question: The monarch indirectly grants royal assent how?
An Order in Council of 13 July 2001 established what?
The Queen was advised to grant royal assent by campaigners in what year?

context: Instead, the monarch directly grants royal assent <b7_0>by <a0_0>Order in Council<b7_0/><a0_0/>. Assent is granted or refused on the advice of the <a1_0><a3_0>Lord Chancellor<a3_0/><a1_0/>. A recent example when assent was refused (or, more correctly, when the Lord Chancellor declined to present the law for assent) was in <a5_0>2007<a5_0/>, concerning <a6_0>reforms to the constitution of the <a2_0>Chief Pleas of Sark<a6_0/><a2_0/>. (A revised version of the proposed reforms was subsequently given assent.) In <b10_0>2011<b10_0/>, campaigners against a law that sought to reduce the number of senators in the states of Jersey petitioned <b9_0>the Privy Council<b9_0/> to advise the Queen to refuse royal assent. An Order in Council of <a4_0>13 July 2011<a4_0/> established <b8_0>new rules<b8_0/> for the consideration of petitions against granting royal assent.
